data.text:
It was 56 years ago, but Jane Russell

remembers clearly the good time she had working with wisecracking Bob Hope on

the set of "The Paleface."

The classic comedy Western, scheduled

for a showing Saturday night at University of the Pacific's Pacific Theatre,

elicited fond memories and laughter from Russell, 83, one of the last surviving

movie queens from the golden age of Hollywood.

"The first two pictures I made,

they made us do takes over and over," she said. "When I got to work with Bob,

it was like I had died and gone to heaven. Everything was one take, not 18.

And he was such fun to work with."

Russell recalled Hope's good nature,

"wonderful sense of humor" and his quickness.

"Those dark eyes were just floating

around the room all the time," Russell said. "He never missed a trick."

Speaking from her home in Santa

Maria, Russell reacted happily to news that Hope's name will adorn the newly

refurbished Bob Hope Fox California Theater.

"That's fabulous!" she said. "I

haven't heard of any other theater doing that, so this is probably the first

time he's been honored that way."

"The Paleface" led Russell to team

up with Hope for a sequel ("Son of Paleface". The two also entertained troops

at military bases around the country.

Once, someone in the audience shouted

out for Russell to rate "the best kisser" she ever worked with. She named Hope

and described his technique in glowing detail.

Hope stood silently until Russell

finished. He then brought the house down with four, well-chosen words: "I wasn't

even trying."

Russell broke into films as the

voluptuous gal pal of Billy the Kid in Howard Hughes' history-bending Western

"The Outlaw."

She described Hughes as "a very

nice guy, sweet and polite," but plagued by his own inexperience and ineptness.

Robert Mitchum and Clark Gable were

among her favorite colleagues, she said, though Gable was "one of the biggest

teasers in the world." He once tried to embarrass her by bringing up the name

of a boyfriend at the wrong time and place.

"I made a fist and threatened to

punch him in the mouth," she said.

Active in charity work, Russell

still appears at film events. On July 23, she spoke to a sold-out house in an

onstage interview at San Francisco's Castro Theater.

In the film "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes,"

she aided young co-star Marilyn Monroe, whom she remembered as "very sweet and

shy," afraid to leave her dressing room and emotionally dependent on her acting

coach.

"She was bound and determined to

be a good actress, but she did get her feelings hurt easily. She was very vulnerable,

so I acted like a big sister," Russell said. "We got along just fine."

Russell said she enjoyed her years

in Hollywood when the film studios ran the show.

"I know they had a great deal more

say about what you did, but they also paid for more," she said. "Today, the

agents run everything. In those days, your studio was your home away from home.

I liked that feeling. The stories were usually good and some of them were wonderful.

And working with Bob Hope, Mitchum and Gable, we just all had a very, very good

time."
